conclusion: Analyze the flow of liquid from points A, B, and C through the baffles to determine if it ends up in container D or E.
The image shows three entry points (A, B, C) at the top, several angled baffles, and two containers (D, E) at the bottom.
Trace the path of the liquid from each entry point step by step.
Entry Points: A, B, and C are at the top, where the liquid is released.
Baffles: There are five angled baffles (yellow, brown, red, gray, and yellow) that redirect the liquid as it falls.
Containers: D and E are at the bottom, with D on the left and E on the right.
The liquid will flow downward due to gravity, and the baffles will redirect it based on their angles.
Point A is on the left side, above a yellow baffle that slopes downward to the right.
The liquid from A will hit the yellow baffle and slide to the right due to the slope.
At the end of the yellow baffle, the liquid will fall straight down.
As it falls, it will encounter the brown baffle on its left side but likely miss it and continue falling.
Next, it will hit the red baffle and slide to the left.
At the end of the red baffle, the liquid falls again toward the left side, where container D is located.
Conclusion for A: The liquid from A will likely flow into container D.
Point B is in the middle, above the same yellow baffle as A, but closer to its right end.
The liquid from B will hit the yellow baffle and slide to the right.
At the end of the yellow baffle, it falls straight down.
As it falls, it will miss the brown and red baffles but will hit the gray baffle.
The liquid will slide to the right along the gray baffle.
At the end of the gray baffle, it falls again, landing on the right side where container E is located.
Conclusion for B: The liquid from B will likely flow into container E.
